title: 105_s143
content: The "Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act of 1997" is also known as the Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act. It covers minimum hospital stay for certain breast cancer treatments under group health plans. The Act includes standards relating to benefits for specific breast cancer treatment. The Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act of 1997 sets minimum hospital stay requirements for mastectomy and lymph node dissection for breast cancer treatment, prohibiting restrictions on hospital length of stay to less than 48 hours for mastectomy and 24 hours for lymph node dissection. The Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act of 1997 mandates minimum hospital stays for mastectomy and lymph node dissection, ensuring at least 48 hours for mastectomy and 24 hours for lymph node dissection. Group health plans and insurance issuers are prohibited from denying coverage to women to avoid these requirements. The Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act of 1997 prohibits plans from avoiding minimum hospital stay requirements by providing incentives to providers or restricting benefits during hospital stays. The Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act of 1997 prohibits plans from providing less favorable benefits for hospital stays following mastectomy or lymph node dissection. The act also clarifies that women are not required to undergo these procedures in a hospital or stay for a fixed period of time. Additionally, the act does not apply to group health plans that do not cover hospital stays for these treatments. The Breast Cancer Patient Protection Act of 1997 allows group health plans to impose deductibles and coinsurance for hospital stays related to mastectomy or lymph node dissection for breast cancer treatment. Plans must comply with notice requirements under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows group health plans to negotiate reimbursement levels with providers for care. State laws may exempt health insurance coverage from certain requirements, such as a 48-hour hospital stay mandate. State laws may exempt health insurance coverage from certain requirements, such as a 48-hour hospital stay mandate following mastectomy or a 24-hour stay after lymph node dissection for breast cancer treatment. The decision on the hospital length of stay is left to the attending provider in consultation with the patient. This provision is not overridden by Section 2723(a)(1) of the Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Act (42 U.S.C. 300gg-23(c)), as amended by Public Law 104-204, is further amended by adding sections 2704 and 2706. Additionally, ERISA is amended by adding a new section to Subpart B of part 7 of title I. SEC. 713. STANDARDS RELATING TO BENEFITS FOR CERTAIN BREAST CANCER TREATMENT. Requirements for Minimum Hospital Stay Following Mastectomy or Lymph Node Dissection include not restricting benefits for hospital stays to less than 48 hours for mastectomy and 24 hours for lymph node dissection in breast cancer treatment. No authorization is required for prescribing the length of stay. The text chunk discusses exceptions and prohibitions related to the minimum hospital stay following mastectomy or lymph node dissection. It states that decisions to discharge a woman early must be made by an attending provider in consultation with the woman. It also prohibits group health plans and health insurance issuers from denying women eligibility based on avoiding the requirements of the section. The text prohibits actions such as providing monetary incentives to women to accept less protection, penalizing providers for following the section, incentivizing providers to act against the section, or restricting benefits during a hospital stay following mastectomy. The section prohibits offering lesser benefits for hospital stays after mastectomy than for other parts of the stay. It clarifies that women are not required to have surgery in a hospital or stay for a fixed period post-surgery. It does not apply to health plans that do not cover hospital stays for mastectomy. The section prohibits imposing higher cost-sharing for hospital stays related to mastectomy or lymph node dissection for breast cancer treatment. It clarifies that women are not obligated to undergo surgery in a hospital or have a fixed post-surgery stay period. This does not apply to health plans that do not cover hospital stays for mastectomy. It clarifies that women are not required to have surgery in a hospital or a fixed post-surgery stay period. Group health plans can negotiate reimbursement levels with providers. Certain States are exempt from the requirements of this section if there is a State law regulating health insurance coverage for breast cancer treatment. The State law may require a minimum hospital length of stay following mastectomy and lymph node dissection for breast cancer treatment. It also mentions amendments to certain sections of the Act related to health insurance coverage for breast cancer treatment. Amendments to the Act include inserting a new item after section 712 regarding health insurance coverage for breast cancer treatment. Standards relating to benefits for certain breast cancer treatment are outlined in a new section added to Part B of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act. The provisions of section 2706 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market, with notice requirements similar to group health plans. State laws may exempt certain health insurance coverage from these requirements. State laws in the individual market may regulate coverage for breast cancer treatment, requiring a minimum hospital stay after mastectomy and lymph node dissection. The length of stay can be determined by the attending provider in consultation with the patient. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to group health plans starting on or after January 1, 1998, while the amendment in subsection (b) applies to individual market health insurance coverage on or after that date.
